250 cases of coronavirus and 15 deaths as of Friday, with the West Coast bearing the brunt of the toll.Washington State has recorded the most cases, 84, and the highest number of deaths, 14. Most of the fatal cases emerged from a Seattle-area nursing home. Officials in King County, Wash., said 15 residents of the facility, Life Care Center, had been taken to hospitals over the past 24 hours.Also in the Seattle area, two Microsoft employees were being treated for the coronavirus, the first from the company to get the diagnosis, a company spokesman said. Microsoft did not close its campus, but has already advised employees to work from home if possible. Emerald City Comic Con, a convention that draws tens of thousands of people to Seattle each year, announced Friday that it would postpone the gathering that was scheduled for next week until the summer.The University of Washington said on Friday that it would cancel in-person classes and have students take classes and final exams remotely while the area grapples with a growing coronavirus outbreak, in a move that other colleges around the country are preparing to follow if the virus becomes more widespread. The university, which has 50,000 students on three campuses across the Seattle region, said the change would begin on Monday and continue through the rest of the winter quarter, which ends March 20.California has treated 70 people for the virus, one of whom has died, and new cases continue to emerge at a worrying rate. Health officials in Yolo County, Calif., near Sacramento, announced their first case on Friday. The county said that the patient was believed to have contracted the illness in the community and was hospitalized.A cruise ship, the Grand Princess , with more than 3,500 people aboard, is being held off the California coast, awaiting the results of tests for coronavirus on dozens of passengers and crew members. Passengers said they had been confined to their rooms.And three students at the University of California, Los Angeles are being tested.On the East Coast, a cluster has emerged in New York State . All but a few of its 33 confirmed cases as of Friday were liked to a New Rochelle man. More than 2,700 people are under some form of quarantine in New York City.The virus has been reported in 20 other states, though most have few cases and none have reported fatalities. They are Arizona, Colorado, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Nebraska, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Jersey, North Carolina, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Tennessee, Texas, Utah and Wisconsin.","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/03/06/world/06virus-sxsw/merlin_135618996_08e637b7-d504-4898-91fd-452ef81b0f5a-superJumbo.jpg","height":1365,"width":2048,"caption":"Billie Eilish performed at South by Southwest in 2018."},"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-1ae6ea51","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-1ae6ea51","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-03-06T21:11:03.043Z","datePublished":"2020-03-06T21:11:03.043Z","headline":"South by Southwest leads long list of canceled events.","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"The 34th annual edition of South by Southwest , the annual festival of music, film and technology in Austin that has become a global draw, was ordered canceled on Friday by local officials over fears about the spread of coronavirus.Festival organizers and government officials had come under intense pressure in recent days to pull the plug, with more than 50,000 people signing an online petition and a growing list of tech companies — among them Apple, Facebook, Twitter and TikTok — announcing their withdrawal.The festival was to have run from March 13-22, with events spread across bars and party spaces in A ustin , in addition to the main conference activities.The cancellation is perhaps the largest collateral damage of the virus so far on the international cultural calendar. Last year, South by Southwest’s various events had a combined attendance of 417,000, including 159,000 who came to the music portion, according to festival figures .Two other large-scale, multi-day gatherings were also called off or pushed back on Friday: Emerald City Comic Con, a convention that draws thousands of people to Seattle each year, was postponed until the summer; and the Ultra Music Festival, an electronic dance music event held annually in Miami, where city officials blocked the event from going on.As the coronavirus spreads in the United States, theaters, museums and concert halls are wary that their establishments could become petri dishes for a virus that is spread person-to-person through respiratory droplets.Mariah Carey postponed her concert in Hawaii. The new James Bond movie, “No Time to Die,” was delayed , a move that prompted many in the film industry to guess that studios would do the same with other films. But thus far, no other release date changes have been announced in the United States.","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/03/05/world/05virus-briefing-NYcity/merlin_169894989_8695276b-b108-46c5-8f61-85b320d801df-superJumbo.jpg","height":1365,"width":2048,"caption":"Times Square in New York this week."},"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-49e909aa","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-49e909aa","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-03-06T19:10:00.663Z","datePublished":"2020-03-06T19:10:00.663Z","headline":"New York City pleads for more tests.","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"New York City officials pleaded in a letter to the federal government on Friday to send more test kits for the new coronavirus , saying that the city’s limited capacity to test for the virus had “impeded our ability to beat back this epidemic.”As of noon on Friday, fewer than 100 people had been tested for the coronavirus in New York City over the past month, according to the city’s Department of Health, even as concerns grew that the virus was circulating largely undetected.State officials said on Friday that so far 33 people in the state had tested positive for the illness — the majority in New Rochelle, just north of New York City. Officials conceded there were likely far more.“I think it’s fair to say we have no idea how many New Yorkers have been infected with this virus without knowing it,” a New York City councilman, Mark Levine, who heads the City Council’s Health Committee, said.Demetre Daskalakis, a deputy commissioner in the Department of Health, said on Thursday afternoon that New York City presently only had enough supply for “around a thousand people” before running out.The city’s letter on Friday to top officials at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention suggested that the limited number of tests was already undermining the city’s efforts, citing “slow federal action.”Americans have struggled to make sense of conflicting information from official authorities, including President Trump and members of his own cabinet. Vice President Mike Pence, who previously vowed that “any American could be tested,” conceded on Thursday that “we don’t have enough tests today to meet what we anticipate will be the demand going forward.”The lack of testing around the country is affecting nursing homes in an unexpected way.An executive with the American Health Care Association, a trade group representing most of the nation’s 15,7000 nursing homes, warned that staff members were far more likely to use protective gear with patients showing any sign of respiratory illness — even as the public is buying masks and the supply chain from China has dwindled.Nursing homes “everywhere” around the country had begun complaining about shortages of masks and gowns, the executive, David Gifford, said.","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/03/06/world/06virus-briefing-stocks/06virus-briefing-stocks-superJumbo.jpg","height":1366,"width":2048,"caption":"Traders at the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, when the S&P 500 fell more than 3 percent."},"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-443cc803","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-443cc803","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-03-06T17:08:58.282Z","datePublished":"2020-03-06T17:08:58.282Z","headline":"Global markets extend their decline.","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"Stocks fell again on Friday , and investors rushed to the safety of government bonds, as Wall Street was gripped by another wave of panic over the coronavirus.The most dramatic move in financial markets on Friday was a sharp drop in yields on government bonds. The yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note sank briefly below 0.7 percent for the first time. Yields move inversely to bond prices, and their slide has come as investors have fled risky investments and put their money into low-interest but safe Treasury bonds.The S&P 500 stock index was down 4 percent in late afternoon, before making up some ground to close down 1.7 percent.A strong report on the American job market on Friday did not change the direction of the markets. The U.S. government said that employers added 273,000 jobs in February, but the data was a snapshot of a point in time when the prevailing sentiment was that the United States would remain relatively unaffected by the coronavirus.Oil prices also sank on Friday as major producers gathered for a critical meeting to try to agree on production cuts to try to manage the falling demand for crude as concerns about coronavirus spread across the globe.","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/03/06/world/06virus-briefing-wuhan/merlin_170008653_b8c4e83b-b190-44ec-a5a8-f1521b199c72-superJumbo.jpg","height":1365,"width":2048,"caption":"An alley in Wuhan, the epicenter of the novel coronavirus outbreak, in Hubei province."},"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-7c004d81","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-7c004d81","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-03-06T15:07:55.902Z","datePublished":"2020-03-06T15:07:55.902Z","headline":"The Chinese province where the virus first appeared reaches a milestone.","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"Hubei, the Chinese province at the center of the coronavirus outbreak, reported on Friday that there were no new infections outside its capital, Wuhan. The news is a major milestone in the government’s all-out campaign to combat an epidemic that has gripped the country since January.In a daily update on its website, China’s National Health Commission reported 126 new infections in Hubei on Friday, but for the first time all of them were in Wuhan, the city of 11 million where the virus is thought to have originated. In total, the country reported 143 new cases on Friday, a sign that Wuhan appears to be the only obvious hot spot of new infections in China.The downward trend is a result of an all-out effort by the Chinese government to contain the spread of the disease. Since January, the government has enacted nationwide quarantine and travel restrictions and placed Hubei under a strict lockdown, effectively penning in 56 million people.The new numbers reflect a steep decline from just a few weeks earlier. At one point in early February, Hubei reported more than 1,400 new cases outside Wuhan in one day. One of the government-appointed Chinese researchers working to control the outbreak told the state-run newspaper People’s Daily on Thursday that, based on the data, he expected Wuhan to hit zero new infections later this month.In the center of the outbreak in China, residents of Wuhan who have been confined to their homes for weeks heckled the visiting vice premier Thursday, with some shouting from their windows: “Fake! Everything is fake!”","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/03/06/world/06virus-europe/merlin_170112321_cd0bbf27-706e-4cbb-a01f-37f5fd6d0c5b-superJumbo.jpg","height":1365,"width":2048,"caption":"Saint Peter's Square in Vatican City on Friday."},"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-4321681a","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-4321681a","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-03-06T13:06:53.521Z","datePublished":"2020-03-06T13:06:53.521Z","headline":"The epidemic grew at an alarming rate in Europe.","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"The number of infections climbed past 7,300 in Europe on Friday — more than doubling in just three days.France, Britain, Spain, the Netherlands, Italy and others each recorded their biggest one-day increases in cases. More than 30 European countries now have cases; 10 of them have at least 100 each.A member of the French Parliament tested positive for the virus. Doctors in Britain warned that the already-strained health care system there could be overwhelmed as the outbreak grows, and the country had its second coronavirus deathMar.In Italy, with the worst outbreak outside of Asia, the toll rose on Friday to more than 4,600 cases, 197 of them fatal, increases of almost 800 infections and 49 deaths from the day before. Only China has had more people die from the new coronavirus.Pope Francis has had a cold for over a week, and on Thursday, a Vatican spokesman, Matteo Bruni, said that the pontiff’s illness was “running its due course.”He also told reporters that the Vatican was “studying measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19,” the disease caused by the new coronavirus, that could affect coming activities involving the pope.Germany, France and Spain, with the next-largest outbreaks in Europe, reported more than 1,700 cases combined, up from fewer than 1,200 on Thursday. In Switzerland, the confirmed caseload doubled, to more than 200.Outside Europe, in Iran’s outbreak, one of the world’s largest, the government reported more than 4,700 infections, an increase of more than 1,200 from the day before.Edouard Philippe, the French prime minister, announced a 15-day school closure in two regions, Oise and Haut-Rhin.France still classifies the virus as a “level two” health threat, meaning that the authorities are trying to limit its spread. But Mr. Philippe and other officials made it clear that the country was heading toward level three, favoring the management of the epidemic by treating the weakest patients, rather than trying to track down every contamination chain in an effort to contain the spread.","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":[{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/03/06/world/06virus-briefing-us/06virus-briefing-us-videoSixteenByNineJumbo1600.jpg","height":900,"width":1600,"caption":"Protective gloves and disinfecting items on a table in a coronavirus pop-up store on Friday in Washington D.C."},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/03/06/world/06virus-briefing-us/merlin_170114082_bf9d0a64-0a57-4445-a3fd-d7ba397225f5-superJumbo.jpg","height":1365,"width":2048,"caption":"Protective gloves and disinfecting items on a table in a coronavirus pop-up store on Friday in Washington D.C."},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/03/06/world/06virus-briefing-us/06virus-briefing-us-mediumSquareAt3X.jpg","height":1800,"width":1800,"caption":"Protective gloves and disinfecting items on a table in a coronavirus pop-up store on Friday in Washington D.C."}],"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-3c64fc3b","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-3c64fc3b","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-03-06T11:05:51.141Z","datePublished":"2020-03-06T11:05:51.141Z","headline":"Here’s what to do if you think you’re sick.","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/03/06/world/06virus-briefing-trump/merlin_170106333_c04046b3-c2cc-4747-b17e-18615abb1fb7-superJumbo.jpg","height":1365,"width":2048,"caption":"President Trump with Alex Azar, the health and human services secretary, as he prepared to sign the emergency spending bill on Friday."},"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-1d355ca5","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-1d355ca5","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-03-06T09:04:48.760Z","datePublished":"2020-03-06T09:04:48.760Z","headline":"Trump signs an $8.3 billion emergency aid bill.","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"Mr. Trump on Friday signed an $8.3 billion emergency spending bill to confront the coronavirus outbreak and decided to visit the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, reversing his decision hours earlier to skip touring the nerve center of the government’s response to the health crisis.As late as 9 p.m. Thursday, Mr. Pence publicly indicated that the trip was still on, telling reporters traveling with him to Washington State that the president would formally approve the spending measure while in Atlanta. “President Trump is expected to sign the legislation tomorrow as he visits the C.D.C. in Atlanta,” Mr. Pence said.But by 11:30 p.m., when the White House issued the president’s public schedule, the visit was no longer on the calendar. A White House official initially said the president had canceled the visit because he did not want to interfere with the work there. But then Mr. Trump told reporters it was called off because of a suspected case of coronavirus at the C.D.C. itself.As he signed the spending bill at the White House on Friday, Mr. Trump said the report of an infection at C.D.C. turned out to be negative. “So I may be going,” he told reporters. “We’re going to see if they can turn it around.”En route to Nashville on Friday to visit the site of a deadly tornado , the White House press secretary, Stephanie Grisham, told reporters that the C.D.C. visit was back on.“What the president said is true,” Ms. Grisham said when asked about the last-minute reversal. She added that test results from the woman at the C.D.C. who was suspected to have the coronavirus came back negative.The president is to travel to Atlanta after his visit in Nashville and then head to Florida, where he is to headline campaign fund-raising events. He is expected to spend the weekend at his Mar-a-Lago estate.","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/03/06/world/06virus-briefing-1/06virus-briefing-1-superJumbo-v3.jpg","height":1365,"width":2048,"caption":"South Korean soldiers spraying disinfectant in Seoul, South Korea, on Friday."},"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-656978b7","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-656978b7","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-03-06T07:03:46.380Z","datePublished":"2020-03-06T07:03:46.380Z","headline":"Cases of infection pass 100,000, and the W.H.O. calls for wider action.","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"The world’s leading health official implored international leaders to unleash the full power of their governments to combat the new coronavirus outbreak.“This is not a drill,” said Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, director general of the World Health Organization . “This is not a time for excuses. This is a time for pulling out all the stops.”But around the world, as the number of cases passed 100,000, governments have displayed signs of paralysis, obfuscation and a desire to protect their own interests, even as death tolls passed 3,200 and global capitals were so threatened by infection that politicians and health officials tested positive for the illness.Dr. Tedros warned that time to contain the virus was running out. “Now is the time to act,” he said. China’s draconian measures to stem the outbreak showed more signs of success on Friday, when Hubei province — the place were the coronavirus first emerged — reported that it had no new cases of infection outside its capital, Wuhan, for the first time.Still, some political leaders around the world seemed more interested in pointing fingers at one another and complaining about tit-for-tat travel restrictions. Japanese citizens have been outraged by the hands-off approach of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe as cases have continued to climb. Lending more outrage, testing has proceeded slowly, leaving many fearful that many infections are going undetected.","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020},{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","image":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/03/06/world/06virus-briefing-russia2/merlin_168526647_a23c0d96-49bf-4d38-86d4-8d35dd05cc3f-superJumbo.jpg","height":1362,"width":2048,"caption":"A metro station in Moscow last month. Russia has sealed its border with China and barred all Chinese citizens from visiting."},"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-258f26e5","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/world/coronavirus-news.html#link-258f26e5","author":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"dateModified":"2020-03-06T05:02:44.000Z","datePublished":"2020-03-06T05:02:44.000Z","headline":"Russia, with few confirmed cases, announces aggressive action to reassure a jittery public.","publisher":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"articleBody":"Russia, if official figures are to be believed, has waged one of the world’s most successful campaigns to halt the spread of the coronavirus, reporting just 10 cases across a vast country with 11 time zones and a border with China more than 2,600 miles long.So it came as a surprise this week when the city authorities in Moscow suddenly announced a raft of sweeping precautionary measures.In a decree published late Wednesday, the capital’s mayor, Sergei S. Sobyanin, ordered all residents who visit China, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, South Korea, or other unspecified “states with an unfavorable coronavirus situation” to report to the municipal government upon their return to the capital and to “self-isolate” for two weeks. The United States has now been added to the list, too.Mr. Sobyanin’s decree, which declared a “regime of heightened readiness” for the capital, created uncertainty and dismay rather than reassurance, raising questions about why a city with just five officially reported cases had suddenly instituted such stringent controls.Russia last month sealed its border with China and then barred all Chinese citizens from visiting, hammering a tourism industry heavily reliant on travelers from China. The flag carrier, Aeroflot, on Wednesday said it was canceling all flights to and from Hong Kong starting this weekend.The jitters have grown so severe, despite the tiny number of officially confirmed cases, that a newsreader on state television suggested late Wednesday that it might be necessary to introduce martial law if the virus were to spread unchecked in Russia.The moves in Moscow follow an alarm this week in St Petersburg, Russia’s second-biggest city, after an Italian exchange student who returned to Russia on Feb. 29 tested positive for the virus. Fellow students in the Italian’s dormitory at the North-Western State Medical University said that they had been ordered not to leave the building.Officials denied that the dormitory, which houses around 700 students, had been placed under quarantine, saying that its residents were simply under “medical supervision.”Another casualty of Russia’s pre-emptive actions has been the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum, an annual event that is usually presided over by President Vladimir V. Putin. This year’s forum in June has been canceled.","copyrightHolder":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"sourceOrganization":{"@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher"},"copyrightYear":2020}]}</script><script data-rh="true" type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"NewsMediaOrganization","@id":"https://www.nytimes.com/#publisher","name":"The New York Times","logo":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/misc/NYT_logo_rss_250x40.png","height":40,"width":250},"diversityPolicy":"https://www.nytco.com/diversity-and-inclusion-at-the-new-york-times/","ethicsPolicy":"https://www.nytco.com/who-we-are/culture/standards-and-ethics/","masthead":"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/admin/the-new-york-times-masthead.html","foundingDate":"1851-09-18","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/","sameAs":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_New_York_Times"}</script>

id="link-42c3d2b8">The U.S. caseload rises past 250, most in Washington State and California.</h2><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Authorities across the United States reported more than 250 cases of coronavirus and 15 deaths as of Friday, with the West Coast bearing the brunt of the toll.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Washington State has recorded the most cases, 84, and the highest number of deaths, 14. Most of the fatal cases emerged from a Seattle-area nursing home. Officials in King County, Wash., said 15 residents of the facility, Life Care Center, had been taken to hospitals over the past 24 hours.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Also in the Seattle area, two Microsoft employees were being treated for the coronavirus, the first from the company to get the diagnosis, a company spokesman said. Microsoft did not close its campus, but has already advised employees to work from home if possible. Emerald City Comic Con, a convention that draws tens of thousands of people to Seattle each year, announced Friday that it would postpone the gathering that was scheduled for next week until the summer.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/us/coronavirus-college-campus-closings.html" title="">University of Washington</a> said on Friday that it would cancel in-person classes and have students take classes and final exams remotely while the area grapples with a growing coronavirus outbreak, in a move that other colleges around the country are preparing to follow if the virus becomes more widespread. The university, which has 50,000 students on three campuses across the Seattle region, said the change would begin on Monday and continue through the rest of the winter quarter, which ends March 20.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">California has treated 70 people for the virus, one of whom has died, and new cases continue to emerge at a worrying rate. Health officials in Yolo County, Calif., near Sacramento, announced their first case on Friday. The county said that the patient was believed to have contracted the illness in the community and was hospitalized.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/05/us/cruise-ship-california.html" title="">A cruise ship, the Grand Princess</a>, with more than 3,500 people aboard, is being held off the California coast, awaiting the results of tests for coronavirus on dozens of passengers and crew members. Passengers said they had been confined to their rooms.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">And three students at the University of California, Los Angeles are being tested.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">On the East Coast, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/nyregion/coronavirus-new-york.html" title="">a cluster has emerged in New York State</a>. All but a few of its 33 confirmed cases as of Friday were liked to a New Rochelle man. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/05/nyregion/coronavirus-new-york-cases.html" title="">More than 2,700 people are under some form of quarantine</a> in New York City.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The virus has been reported in 20 other states, though most have few cases and none have reported fatalities. They are Arizona, Colorado, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Nebraska, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Jersey, North Carolina, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Tennessee, Texas, Utah and Wisconsin.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-1ae6ea51">South by Southwest leads long list of canceled events.</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The 34th annual edition of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/arts/music/sxsw-cancelled.html" title="">South by Southwest</a>, the annual festival of music, film and technology in Austin that has become a global draw, was ordered <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/arts/music/sxsw-cancelled.html" title="">canceled</a> on Friday by local officials over fears about the spread of coronavirus.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Festival organizers and government officials had come under intense pressure in recent days to pull the plug, with more than 50,000 people signing an online petition and a growing list of tech companies — among them Apple, Facebook, Twitter and TikTok — announcing their withdrawal.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The festival was to have run from March 13-22, with events spread across bars and party spaces in A<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/arts/music/sxsw-cancelled.html" title="">ustin</a>, in addition to the main conference activities.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The cancellation is perhaps the largest collateral damage of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/arts/music/sxsw-cancelled.html" title="">virus</a> so far on the international cultural calendar. Last year, South by Southwest’s various events had a combined attendance of 417,000, including 159,000 who came to the music portion, according to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://explore.sxsw.com/hubfs/2019-SXSW-Event-Stats_9-10-19.pdf?__hstc=66818801.52a968f693bfa47862e1ef151801ae20.1583166647148.1583166647148.1583166647148.1&__hssc=66818801.22.1583166647148" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">festival figures</a>.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Two other large-scale, multi-day gatherings were also called off or pushed back on Friday: Emerald City Comic Con, a convention that draws thousands of people to Seattle each year, was postponed until the summer; and the Ultra Music Festival, an electronic dance music event held annually in Miami, where city officials blocked the event from going on.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As the coronavirus spreads in the United States, theaters, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/arts/covid-19-movies-theaters-concerts-museums.html" title="">museums and concert halls are wary </a>that their establishments could become petri dishes for a virus that is spread person-to-person through respiratory droplets.</p><div id="NYT_MID_MAIN_CONTENT_REGION" class="css-9tf9ac"><section id="2020-02-27-covid19-newsletter-signup" class="css-l08pwh interactive-content interactive-size-medium"><div class="css-17ih8de interactive-body"><!--

</div></section></div><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mariah Carey <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/MariahCarey/status/1234979098922848257?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1234979098922848257&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.vulture.com%2F2020%2F03%2Fevents-cancelled-coronavirus.html" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">postponed her concert</a> in Hawaii. The new James Bond movie, “No Time to Die,” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/04/movies/james-bond-coronavirus.html?searchResultPosition=2" title="">was delayed</a>, a move that prompted many in the film industry to guess that studios would do the same with other films. But thus far, no other release date changes have been announced in the United States.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-49e909aa">New York City pleads for more tests.</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">New York City officials pleaded in a letter to the federal government on Friday <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/nyregion/coronavirus-new-york.html" title="">to send more test kits for the new coronavirus</a>, saying that the city’s limited capacity to test for the virus had “impeded our ability to beat back this epidemic.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As of noon on Friday, fewer than 100 people had been tested for the coronavirus in New York City over the past month, according to the city’s Department of Health, even as concerns grew that the virus was circulating largely undetected.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">State officials said on Friday that so far 33 people in the state had tested positive for the illness — the majority in New Rochelle, just north of New York City. Officials conceded there were likely far more.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“I think it’s fair to say we have no idea how many New Yorkers have been infected with this virus without knowing it,” a New York City councilman, Mark Levine, who heads the City Council’s Health Committee, said.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Demetre Daskalakis, a deputy commissioner in the Department of Health, said on Thursday afternoon that New York City presently only had enough supply for “around a thousand people” before running out.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The city’s letter on Friday to top officials at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention suggested that the limited number of tests was already undermining the city’s efforts, citing “slow federal action.”</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Americans have struggled to make sense of conflicting information from official authorities, including President Trump and members of his own cabinet. Vice President Mike Pence, who previously vowed that “any American could be tested,” conceded on Thursday that “we don’t have enough tests today to meet what we anticipate will be the demand going forward.”</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The lack of testing around the country is affecting nursing homes in an unexpected way.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">An executive with the American Health Care Association, a trade group representing most of the nation’s 15,7000 nursing homes, warned that staff members were far more likely to use protective gear with patients showing any sign of respiratory illness — even as the public is buying masks and the supply chain from China has dwindled.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Nursing homes “everywhere” around the country had begun complaining about shortages of masks and gowns, the executive, David Gifford, said.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-443cc803">Global markets extend their decline.</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Stocks <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/business/stock-markets-today.html" title="">fell again on Friday</a>, and investors rushed to the safety of government bonds, as Wall Street was gripped by another wave of panic over the coronavirus.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The most dramatic move in financial markets on Friday was a sharp drop in yields on government bonds. The yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note sank briefly below 0.7 percent for the first time. Yields move inversely to bond prices, and their slide has come as investors have fled risky investments and put their money into low-interest but safe Treasury bonds.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The S&P 500 stock index was down 4 percent in late afternoon, before making up some ground to close down 1.7 percent.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A strong report on the<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/business/economy/jobs-report.html" title=""> American job market</a> on Friday did not change the direction of the markets. The U.S. government said that employers added 273,000 jobs in February, but the data was a snapshot of a point in time when the prevailing sentiment was that the United States would remain relatively unaffected by the coronavirus.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Oil prices also sank on Friday as major producers gathered for a critical meeting to try to agree on production cuts to try to manage the falling demand for crude as concerns about coronavirus spread across the globe.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-7c004d81">The Chinese province where the virus first appeared reaches a milestone.</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Hubei, the Chinese province at the center of the coronavirus outbreak, reported on Friday that there were no new infections outside its capital, Wuhan. The news is a major milestone in the government’s all-out campaign to combat an epidemic that has gripped the country since January.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a daily update on its website, China’s National Health Commission reported 126 new infections in Hubei on Friday, but for the first time all of them were in Wuhan, the city of 11 million where the virus is thought to have originated. In total, the country reported 143 new cases on Friday, a sign that Wuhan appears to be the only obvious hot spot of new infections in China.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The downward trend is a result of an all-out effort by the Chinese government to contain the spread of the disease. Since January, the government has enacted nationwide quarantine and travel restrictions and placed Hubei under a strict lockdown, effectively penning in 56 million people.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The new numbers reflect a steep decline from just a few weeks earlier. At one point in early February, Hubei reported more than 1,400 new cases outside Wuhan in one day. One of the government-appointed Chinese researchers working to control the outbreak <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://yuqing.people.com.cn/n1/2020/0305/c209043-31619091.html" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">told the state-run newspaper People’s Daily</a> on Thursday that, based on the data, he expected Wuhan to hit zero new infections later this month.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In the center of the outbreak in China, residents of Wuhan who have been confined to their homes for weeks heckled the visiting vice premier Thursday, with some shouting from their windows: “Fake! Everything is fake!”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-4321681a">The epidemic grew at an alarming rate in Europe.</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The number of infections climbed past 7,300 in Europe on Friday — more than doubling in just three days.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">France, Britain, Spain, the Netherlands, Italy and others each recorded their biggest one-day increases in cases. More than 30 European countries now have cases; 10 of them have at least 100 each.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">A member of the French Parliament tested positive for the virus. Doctors in Britain warned that the already-strained health care system there could be overwhelmed as the outbreak grows, and the country had its second coronavirus deathMar.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In Italy, with the worst outbreak outside of Asia, the toll rose on Friday to more than 4,600 cases, 197 of them fatal, increases of almost 800 infections and 49 deaths from the day before. Only China has had more people die from the new coronavirus.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Pope Francis has had a cold for over a week, and on Thursday, a Vatican spokesman, Matteo Bruni, said that the pontiff’s illness was “running its due course.”</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">He also told reporters that the Vatican was “studying measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19,” the disease caused by the new coronavirus, that could affect coming activities involving the pope.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-cfo9c3"></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Germany, France and Spain, with the next-largest outbreaks in Europe, reported more than 1,700 cases combined, up from fewer than 1,200 on Thursday. In Switzerland, the confirmed caseload doubled, to more than 200.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Outside Europe, in Iran’s outbreak, one of the world’s largest, the government reported more than 4,700 infections, an increase of more than 1,200 from the day before.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Edouard Philippe, the French prime minister, announced a 15-day school closure in two regions, Oise and Haut-Rhin.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">France still classifies the virus as a “level two” health threat, meaning that the authorities are trying to limit its spread. But Mr. Philippe and other officials made it clear that the country was heading toward level three, favoring the management of the epidemic by treating the weakest patients, rather than trying to track down every contamination chain in an effort to contain the spread.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-3c64fc3b">Here’s what to do if you think you’re sick.</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-1d355ca5">Trump signs an $8.3 billion emergency aid bill.</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Trump on Friday signed an $8.3 billion emergency spending bill to confront the coronavirus outbreak and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/06/us/politics/trump-coronavirus-cdc.html" title="">decided to visit the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a> in Atlanta, reversing his decision hours earlier to skip touring the nerve center of the government’s response to the health crisis.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As late as 9 p.m. Thursday, Mr. Pence publicly indicated that the trip was still on, telling reporters traveling with him to Washington State that the president would formally approve the spending measure while in Atlanta. “President Trump is expected to sign the legislation tomorrow as he visits the C.D.C. in Atlanta,” Mr. Pence said.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But by 11:30 p.m., when the White House issued the president’s public schedule, the visit was no longer on the calendar. A White House official initially said the president had canceled the visit because he did not want to interfere with the work there. But then Mr. Trump told reporters it was called off because of a suspected case of coronavirus at the C.D.C. itself.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">As he signed the spending bill at the White House on Friday, Mr. Trump said the report of an infection at C.D.C. turned out to be negative. “So I may be going,” he told reporters. “We’re going to see if they can turn it around.”</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">En route to Nashville on Friday to visit the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/03/us/nashville-tornado-live.html" title="">site of a deadly tornado</a>, the White House press secretary, Stephanie Grisham, told reporters that the C.D.C. visit was back on.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“What the president said is true,” Ms. Grisham said when asked about the last-minute reversal. She added that test results from the woman at the C.D.C. who was suspected to have the coronavirus came back negative.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The president is to travel to Atlanta after his visit in Nashville and then head to Florida, where he is to headline campaign fund-raising events. He is expected to spend the weekend at his Mar-a-Lago estate.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-656978b7">Cases of infection pass 100,000, and the W.H.O. calls for wider action.</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The world’s leading health official implored international leaders to unleash the full power of their governments to combat the new coronavirus outbreak.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">“This is not a drill,” said Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, director general of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.who.int/dg/speeches/detail/who-director-general-s-opening-remarks-at-the-media-briefing-on-covid-19---5-march-2020" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">World Health Organization</a>. “This is not a time for excuses. This is a time for pulling out all the stops.”</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">But around the world, as the number of cases passed 100,000, governments have displayed signs of paralysis, obfuscation and a desire to protect their own interests, even as death tolls passed 3,200 and global capitals were so threatened by infection that politicians and health officials tested positive for the illness.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Dr. Tedros warned that time to contain the virus was running out. “Now is the time to act,” he said. China’s draconian measures to stem the outbreak showed more signs of success on Friday, when Hubei province — the place were the coronavirus first emerged — reported that it had no new cases of infection outside its capital, Wuhan, for the first time.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Still, some political leaders around the world seemed more interested in pointing fingers at one another and complaining about tit-for-tat travel restrictions. Japanese citizens have been outraged by the hands-off approach of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe as cases have continued to climb. Lending more outrage, testing has proceeded slowly, leaving many fearful that many infections are going undetected.</p><h2 class="css-3ez4hu eoo0vm40" id="link-258f26e5">Russia, with few confirmed cases, announces aggressive action to reassure a jittery public.</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia, if official figures are to be believed, has waged one of the world’s most successful campaigns to halt the spread of the coronavirus, reporting just 10 cases across a vast country with 11 time zones and a border with China more than 2,600 miles long.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">So it came as a surprise this week when the city authorities in Moscow suddenly announced a raft of sweeping precautionary measures.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">In a decree published late Wednesday, the capital’s mayor, Sergei S. Sobyanin, ordered all residents who visit China, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, South Korea, or other unspecified “states with an unfavorable coronavirus situation” to report to the municipal government upon their return to the capital and to “self-isolate” for two weeks. The United States has now been added to the list, too.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Mr. Sobyanin’s decree, which declared a “regime of heightened readiness” for the capital, created uncertainty and dismay rather than reassurance, raising questions about why a city with just five officially reported cases had suddenly instituted such stringent controls.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Russia last month sealed its border with China and then barred all Chinese citizens from visiting, hammering a tourism industry heavily reliant on travelers from China. The flag carrier, Aeroflot, on Wednesday said it was canceling all flights to and from Hong Kong starting this weekend.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The jitters have grown so severe, despite the tiny number of officially confirmed cases, that a newsreader on state television suggested late Wednesday that it might be necessary to introduce martial law if the virus were to spread unchecked in Russia.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">The moves in Moscow follow an alarm this week in St Petersburg, Russia’s second-biggest city, after an Italian exchange student who returned to Russia on Feb. 29 tested positive for the virus. Fellow students in the Italian’s dormitory at the North-Western State Medical University said that they had been ordered not to leave the building.</p><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Officials denied that the dormitory, which houses around 700 students, had been placed under quarantine, saying that its residents were simply under “medical supervision.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-exrw3m evys1bk0">Another casualty of Russia’s pre-emptive actions has been the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum, an annual event that is usually presided over by President Vladimir V. Putin. This year’s forum in June has been canceled.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-jwz2nf etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Peter Baker, Andrew Higgins, Declan Walsh, Michael Gold, Matt Richtel, Alan Yuhas, Adeel Hassan,<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>Aurelien Breeden, David Halbfinger, Mohammed Najib,<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>Marc Santora, Benjamin Mueller, Russell Goldman, Amy Qin, Elaine Yu, Javier C. Hernández, Max Fisher, Ben Dooley, Mike Isaac, David Yaffe-Bellany, Raillan Brooks and Karen Weise.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div></section><div></div><div id="NYT_BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT_REGION"><section id="styln-faq-coronavirus" class="css-l08pwh interactive-content interactive-size-medium"><div class="css-17ih8de interactive-body"><!--

                      <h1 class="g-headline" id="g-inlineguide-headline">The Coronavirus Outbreak</h1>

                      <ul class="g-inlineguide-list">
                          
                                  <li>
                                      <h2 class="g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type">Answers to your most common questions:</h2>
                                      <p class="g-inlineguide-date">Updated March 2, 2020</p>

                                      
                                          
                                              <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
                                                  <li>
                                                      <strong>What is a coronavirus?</strong><br> It is a novel virus named for the crownlike spikes that protrude from its surface. The coronavirus can infect both animals and people and can cause <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/what-is-coronavirus.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_guide">a range of respiratory illnesses</a> from the common cold to lung lesions and pneumonia.
                                                  </li>
                                              </ul>
                                          

                                      
                                          
                                              <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
                                                  <li>
                                                      <strong>How contagious is the virus?</strong><br> It seems to <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/asia/china-coronavirus-contain.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_guide?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&variant=show&region=TOP_BANNER&context=storyline_menu#transmission">spread very easily</a> from person to person, especially in homes, hospitals and other confined spaces. The pathogen can travel through the air, enveloped in tiny respiratory droplets that are produced when a sick person breathes, talks, coughs or sneezes.
                                                  </li>
                                              </ul>
                                          

                                      
                                          
                                              <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
                                                  <li>
                                                      <strong>Where has the virus spread?</strong><br> The virus, which originated in Wuhan, China, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/coronavirus-maps.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_guide">has sickened more than 89,700</a> in at least 67 countries and more than 3,000 have died. The spread has slowed in China, but is picking up speed in Europe and <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/01/world/coronavirus-news.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_guide">the United States</a>.
                                                  </li>
                                              </ul>
                                          

                                      
                                          
                                              <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
                                                  <li>
                                                      <strong>What symptoms should I look out for?</strong><br>Symptoms, which can take between <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/world/asia/china-coronavirus-contain.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_guide">two to 14 days to appear</a>, include fever, cough and difficulty breathing or shortness of breath. Milder cases may resemble the flu or a bad cold, but people may be able to pass on the virus even before they develop symptoms.
                                                  </li>
                                              </ul>
                                          

                                      
                                          
                                              <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
                                                  <li>
                                                      <strong>How do I keep myself and others safe?</strong><br> <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/prepare-for-coronavirus.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_guide">Washing your hands</a> frequently is the most important thing you can do, along with staying at home when you’re sick and <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/02/well/live/coronavirus-spread-transmission-face-touching-hands.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_guide">avoiding touching your face.</a>
                                                  </li>
                                              </ul>
                                          

                                      
                                          
                                              <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
                                                  <li>
                                                      <strong>How can I prepare for a possible outbreak?</strong><br> <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/prepare-for-coronavirus.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_guide">Keep a 30-day supply of essential medicines.</a> Get a flu shot. Have essential household items on hand. Have a support system in place for elderly family members.
                                                  </li>
                                              </ul>
                                          

                                      
                                          
                                              <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
                                                  <li>
                                                      <strong>What if I’m traveling?</strong><br> The C.D.C. has<a href="https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices"> </a><a href="https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices">advised against</a> all non-essential travel to South Korea, China, Italy and Iran. And the agency has warned older and at-risk travelers to avoid Japan.
                                                  </li>
                                              </ul>
                                          

                                      
                                          
                                              <ul class="g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle" id="g-inlineguide-item-list">
                                                  <li>
                                                      <strong>How long will it take to develop a treatment or vaccine?</strong><br> Several drugs are<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/06/health/coronavirus-treatments.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_guide"> </a><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/06/health/coronavirus-treatments.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&region=BELOW_MAIN_CONTENT&context=storyline_guide">being tested</a>, and some initial findings are expected soon. A vaccine to stop the spread is still at least a year away.
                                                  </li>
                                              </ul>

In total, the country reported 143 new cases on Friday, a sign that Wuhan appears to be the only obvious hot spot of new infections in China.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2Q1OGY5MzJjLTEyYzgtNWQxMS1hYzI0LTA2MjUwNTkzY2RlNQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.95.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The downward trend is a result of an all-out effort by the Chinese government to contain the spread of the disease. metro station in Moscow last month. Russia has sealed its border with China and barred all Chinese citizens from visiting.","__typename":"TextOnlyDocumentBlock"},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2Q1OGY5MzJjLTEyYzgtNWQxMS1hYzI0LTA2MjUwNTkzY2RlNQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.170.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Russia, if official figures are to be believed, has waged one of the world’s most successful campaigns to halt the spread of the coronavirus, reporting just 10 cases across a vast country with 11 time zones and a border with China more than 2,600 miles long.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2Q1OGY5MzJjLTEyYzgtNWQxMS1hYzI0LTA2MjUwNTkzY2RlNQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.172.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"So it came as a surprise this week when the city authorities in Moscow suddenly announced a raft of sweeping precautionary measures.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2Q1OGY5MzJjLTEyYzgtNWQxMS1hYzI0LTA2MjUwNTkzY2RlNQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.174.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"In a decree published late Wednesday, the capital’s mayor, Sergei S. Sobyanin, ordered all residents who visit China, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, South Korea, or other unspecified “states with an unfavorable coronavirus situation” to report to the municipal government upon their return to the capital and to “self-isolate” for two weeks. The United States has now been added to the list, too.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2Q1OGY5MzJjLTEyYzgtNWQxMS1hYzI0LTA2MjUwNTkzY2RlNQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.176.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Mr. Sobyanin’s decree, which declared a “regime of heightened readiness” for the capital, created uncertainty and dismay rather than reassurance, raising questions about why a city with just five officially reported cases had suddenly instituted such stringent controls.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2Q1OGY5MzJjLTEyYzgtNWQxMS1hYzI0LTA2MjUwNTkzY2RlNQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.178.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Russia last month sealed its border with China and then barred all Chinese citizens from visiting, hammering a tourism industry heavily reliant on travelers from China. The flag carrier, Aeroflot, on Wednesday said it was canceling all flights to and from Hong Kong starting this weekend.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2Q1OGY5MzJjLTEyYzgtNWQxMS1hYzI0LTA2MjUwNTkzY2RlNQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.180.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The jitters have grown so severe, despite the tiny number of officially confirmed cases, that a newsreader on state television suggested late Wednesday that it might be necessary to introduce martial law if the virus were to spread unchecked in Russia.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2Q1OGY5MzJjLTEyYzgtNWQxMS1hYzI0LTA2MjUwNTkzY2RlNQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.182.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The moves in Moscow follow an alarm this week in St Petersburg, Russia’s second-biggest city, after an Italian exchange student who returned to Russia on Feb. 29 tested positive for the virus. Fellow students in the Italian’s dormitory at the North-Western State Medical University said that they had been ordered not to leave the building.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2Q1OGY5MzJjLTEyYzgtNWQxMS1hYzI0LTA2MjUwNTkzY2RlNQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.184.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Officials denied that the dormitory, which houses around 700 students, had been placed under quarantine, saying that its residents were simply under “medical supervision.”","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2Q1OGY5MzJjLTEyYzgtNWQxMS1hYzI0LTA2MjUwNTkzY2RlNQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.186.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Another casualty of Russia’s pre-emptive actions has been the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum, an annual event that is usually presided over by President Vladimir V. Putin. This year’s forum in June has been canceled.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2Q1OGY5MzJjLTEyYzgtNWQxMS1hYzI0LTA2MjUwNTkzY2RlNQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.188.title.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"VIRUS IN       \u003Cdiv id=\"truncate-content\" class=\"g-inlineguide-content\"\u003E\n\n                      \u003Ch1 class=\"g-headline\" id=\"g-inlineguide-headline\"\u003EThe Coronavirus Outbreak\u003C\u002Fh1\u003E\n\n                      \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-list\"\u003E\n                          \n                                  \u003Cli\u003E\n                                      \u003Ch2 class=\"g-inlineguide-list-header g-optimize-type\"\u003EAnswers to your most common questions:\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n                                      \u003Cp class=\"g-inlineguide-date\"\u003EUpdated March 2, 2020\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\n                                      \n                                          \n                                              \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n                                                  \u003Cli\u003E\n                                                      \u003Cstrong\u003EWhat is a coronavirus?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cbr\u003E It is a novel virus named for the crownlike spikes that protrude from its surface. The coronavirus can infect both animals and people and can cause \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Farticle\u002Fwhat-is-coronavirus.html\"\u003Ea range of respiratory illnesses\u003C\u002Fa\u003E from the common cold to lung lesions and pneumonia.\n                                                  \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n                                              \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n                                          \n\n                                      \n                                          \n                                              \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n                                                  \u003Cli\u003E\n                                                      \u003Cstrong\u003EHow contagious is the virus?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cbr\u003E It seems to \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2020\u002Fworld\u002Fasia\u002Fchina-coronavirus-contain.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-coronavirus&variant=show&region=TOP_BANNER&context=storyline_menu#transmission\"\u003Espread very easily\u003C\u002Fa\u003E from person to person, especially in homes, hospitals and other confined spaces. The pathogen can travel through the air, enveloped in tiny respiratory droplets that are produced when a sick person breathes, talks, coughs or sneezes.\n                                                  \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n                                              \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n                                          \n\n                                      \n                                          \n                                              \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n                                                  \u003Cli\u003E\n                                                      \u003Cstrong\u003EWhere has the virus spread?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cbr\u003E The virus, which originated in Wuhan, China, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2020\u002Fworld\u002Fcoronavirus-maps.html\"\u003Ehas sickened more than 89,700\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in at least 67 countries and more than 3,000 have died. The spread has slowed in China, but is picking up speed in Europe and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F01\u002Fworld\u002Fcoronavirus-news.html\"\u003Ethe United States\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\n                                                  \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n                                              \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n                                          \n\n                                      \n                                          \n                                              \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n                                                  \u003Cli\u003E\n                                                      \u003Cstrong\u003EWhat symptoms should I look out for?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cbr\u003ESymptoms, which can take between \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2020\u002Fworld\u002Fasia\u002Fchina-coronavirus-contain.html\"\u003Etwo to 14 days to appear\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, include fever, cough and difficulty breathing or shortness of breath. Milder cases may resemble the flu or a bad cold, but people may be able to pass on the virus even before they develop symptoms.\n                                                  \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n                                              \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n                                          \n\n                                      \n                                          \n                                              \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n                                                  \u003Cli\u003E\n                                                      \u003Cstrong\u003EHow do I keep myself and others safe?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cbr\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Farticle\u002Fprepare-for-coronavirus.html\"\u003EWashing your hands\u003C\u002Fa\u003E frequently is the most important thing you can do, along with staying at home when you’re sick and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F02\u002Fwell\u002Flive\u002Fcoronavirus-spread-transmission-face-touching-hands.html\"\u003Eavoiding touching your face.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n                                                  \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n                                              \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n                                          \n\n                                      \n                                          \n                                              \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n                                                  \u003Cli\u003E\n                                                      \u003Cstrong\u003EHow can I prepare for a possible outbreak?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cbr\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Farticle\u002Fprepare-for-coronavirus.html\"\u003EKeep a 30-day supply of essential medicines.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Get a flu shot. Have essential household items on hand. Have a support system in place for elderly family members.\n                                                  \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n                                              \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n                                          \n\n                                      \n                                          \n                                              \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n                                                  \u003Cli\u003E\n                                                      \u003Cstrong\u003EWhat if I’m traveling?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cbr\u003E The C.D.C. has\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwwwnc.cdc.gov\u002Ftravel\u002Fnotices\"\u003E \u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwwwnc.cdc.gov\u002Ftravel\u002Fnotices\"\u003Eadvised against\u003C\u002Fa\u003E all non-essential travel to South Korea, China, Italy and Iran. And the agency has warned older and at-risk travelers to avoid Japan.\n                                                  \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n                                              \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n                                          \n\n                                      \n                                          \n                                              \u003Cul class=\"g-inlineguide-item-list g-inlineguide-list-circle\" id=\"g-inlineguide-item-list\"\u003E\n                                                  \u003Cli\u003E\n                                                      \u003Cstrong\u003EHow long will it take to develop a treatment or vaccine?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cbr\u003E Several drugs are\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F02\u002F06\u002Fhealth\u002Fcoronavirus-treatments.html\"\u003E \u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F02\u002F06\u002Fhealth\u002Fcoronavirus-treatments.html\"\u003Ebeing tested\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, and some initial findings are expected soon. A vaccine to stop the spread is still at least a year away.\n                                                  \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n                                              \u003C\u002Ful\u003E\n                                          \n\n                                      \n                                  \u003C\u002Fli\u003E\n                          \n
